_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of FS Cooperative are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accident release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with Wautoma Fire Department, Waushara Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. The stationary source and the regulated substance handled.

The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 430 Pickle Row, is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and handling system consists of 1-18,000 gallon storage tank, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 200,000 pounds; this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks.

4.The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA?s Accidental Release Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of ?Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1?, published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by the state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety an Health Administration (OSHA), 29CFR 1910.111, ?Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia?. Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our accident release prevention program.

5. Five year accident history.

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
-    have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor 
-    to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuatio

ns, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

6. The emergency response program.

The facility has:
-    written emergency action plan, in accordance with the OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
-    provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as the SARA Title III (EPCRA)

In the event of any emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Wautoma Fire Department and the Waushara LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency. Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both fire department and LEPC.

7. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no specific safety recommendation for implementation at this time.
